Another one is Mundo's Sadism, which really has nothing to do with sadism.  Names are a good start to thematics, but it can't stop there.

We hid lots of fours in every part of Jhin. His kit, art, sound, and VO.   He also has 16 pop culture references in him.  (Unless something got cut without my knowledge.) Breaking the writers "rule of three" for his lore and VO was frequently painful but I think it was worthwhile.

One of the things champ team tries to do with these mini-themes is--quadruple down on them.  So that even if you don't consciously notice them while playing the game- you will subconsciously feel them.     And for a character who players should count shots with-- this seemed especially true.

But 4 passives? That's just ewww. Why can't anything be "simple" now adays without having to have multiple dashes, AoE heals, mega crit damage, windwalls, stuns, shields, and a 102473084928332 amount of passives to go along with?

Why does everything need to be "simple" nowadays?

More complexity in the kits provide counterplay. Without counterplay, you'd get bored as hell pretty damn quick. Go play Adventure Time: Battle Party and you'll see what I mean

There's also a thing called too much complexity. I heard somewhere that they wanted to go back to simple but they are still spewing out complex champs like Jhin. Sure you can make a new champion that brings new stuff to the table but you don't need to keep overloading it.

It's not a meme, it's a theme.

Four is known in some cultures to represent death, in a similar manner to thirteen in the West (because thirteen people sat at the last supper, and one was a traitor).

Considering his theme is about killing or whatever, it kind of makes sense.

So it fits.

Considering that Jhin is from Ionia, the number 4 aspect of his design is probably a reference to the association of Death and Four in Asian languages.

Specifically, in any languages based on Hanzi such as Mandarin, Japanese, or Cantonese, the number Four sounds like the word for Death.
It is considered unlucky to have 4 of anything in many Asian cultures. Often one would find the number to be omitted in similar ways Western cultures omit 13.
